description.narrative: To assist countries in the development and strengthening of their national Access to Genetic Resources and Benefit-Sharing (ABS) frameworks, human resources and administrative capabilities to implement the Nagoya Protocol.
seat of a first-order administrative division

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1- Number of national ABS law/regulation/policy proposals developed and/or strengthened with the participation of key stakeholders including indigenous peoples and ILCs.
2- Increase by X% in the capacities of national and state competent authorities and related agencies to develop, implement, and enforce national ABS domestic legislation, administrative or policy measures for ABS - including a CHM, as measured by the UNDP ABS Capacity Development Scorecard
3- Number of ABS partnerships established with project support for the development of products for commercial purposes

comment.narrative:
1.No ABS-related law/ regulation in place (Honduras, Uruguay, Botswana, Comoros, Seychelles, Kazakhstan, Mongolia, Myanmar, Samoa, Tajikistan); Pre- Nagoya protocol measures on ABS in place (Ethiopia, Kenya, South Africa); Some legal ABS measures in place (Albania); Some legal acts to regulate the access to genetic resources in place, but they do not include all the issues relevant to the Nagoya Protocol (Belarus); Draft ABS legislation pre-dating the Nagoya Protocol (Egypt); Legal framework in place (India); Amendment of the Environment Protection Law in process (Jordan); Legal amendment to introduce ABS in progress, some draft sectoral rules in process (Sudan); Some ABS provisions are included in the existing regulation for biodiversity research (Dominican Republic); ABS comprehensive legal framework in place (Ecuador); and specific ABS legal framework in place (Panama).
2.Albania: 42.42%, Belarus: 30.30%, Egypt: 16.67 %, India: 53.05 %, Jordan: 22.73 %, Sudan: 24.24 %, Colombia: 74.24%, Dominican Republic: 28.79%, Ecuador: 45.45%, Honduras: 28.79%, Panama: 40. 91%, Uruguay: 12.12%, Botswana: 18.67%, Comoros: 13.64%, Ethiopia: 65.15%, Kenya: 49.97%, Rwanda: 68.18%, Seychelles: 45.45%, South Africa: 75.76%, Kazakhstan: 35.0%, Mongolia: 30.0%, Myanmar: 20.0%, Samoa: 35.0% and Tajikistan: 15.0 %
3.Zero (0) for all 24 COs Albania, Belarus, Botswana, Colombia, Comoros, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, India, Jordan, Sudan, Honduras, Panama, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Seychelles, South Africa, Kazakhstan, Mongolia, Myanmar, Samoa, Tajikistan and Uruguay.

1. 22
2. Albania: 52.42%; Belarus: 50.30%; Egypt: 36.67 %; India: 58.05 %; Jordan: 42.73%; Sudan: 44.24%; Colombia: 94.24%; Dominican Republic: 58.79%; Ecuador: 65.45%; Honduras: 58.79%; Panama: 70.91%; Uruguay: 12.12%; Botswana: 50%; Comoros: 50%; Ethiopia: 90%; Kenya: 70%; Rwanda: 50%; Seychelles: 80%; South Africa: 85%; Kazakhstan: 50 to 75%; Mongolia: 45 to 65%; Myanmar: 35 to 55%; Samoa: 50 to 75%; Tajikistan: 30 to 50%
3. 1 (per country in 21 countries) 2 in Mongolia and Uruguay (none in Ecuador)

1. All the countries have developed their draft ABS legal frameworks and, therefore, they have achieved their target. 3 countries have approved during this year different ABS legal instruments. Albania has introduced some amendments to regulate ABS into the Law for the Protection of Biodiversity. Comoros has approved the law that implements the Nagoya Protocol on Access to Genetic Resources and the Fair and Equitable Sharing of the Benefits Arising from their Utilization. Finally, Uruguay that had a provisional ABS regime, it has approved its ABS Regulation, including an agreement to designate the National Intellectual Property Office as a checkpoint of the Nagoya Protocol. Although the target has been achieved, the project continues pushing for the approval of the ABS laws and regulations as only few countries have managed to formally approve them (5 out of 21: Albania, Comoros, Dominican Republic, Panama and Uruguay). Colombia and Rwanda, originally without a concrete target on this output, have also conducted different activities to support the improvement of their ABS legal systems.
2- The target has been achieved in the 10 countries that completed the implementation of the project before June 30, 2020, with the exception of Panama (59%), due to many changes in personnel within the competent national authority, which impacts on the direction of progress of the issue at the institutional level. Ethiopia has not reached its target (90%) but it ended very close to it (86%). Belarus (77%), Botswana (58%), Dominican Republic (81%), Jordan (61%), Mongolia (52%), Myanmar (59%), Sudan (65%), Uruguay (52%) have clearly exceeded their original percentage of increase, in some cases they have doubled them. The target is on track as not all the countries have finished the implementation of the project and this specific criterion is measured at the end of the project to check the total increase in their capacities.
3. All the countries (22) have already supported different biodiscovery projects (39 ouf of 24 initially expected) but also have developed strategies to promote bioprospecting activities in their countries for the active valorization of their genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge or even a coordinating network which blends partnerships to optimize development and enhance growth in the South African bio trade and bio prospecting sector (BioProducts Advancement Network South Africa, BioPANZA). Ecuador, initially not included in this specific output, has supported a biodiscovery partnership that includes not only a research institution from the USA, but a collaboration agreement with the indigenous community of San Jose de Payamino as key partners. Some of these collaborations have ended in the request of ABS commercial permits that shows the very concrete commercial potential of some of these biodiscovery projects. 11 out 22 countries have signed ABS commercial agreements. During this year, 5 countries (Colombia-5; Ethiopia- 6; India; Myanmar- 1; South Africa- 2; Sudan-1) signed 15 ABS commercial agreements. And 4 additional countries (Botswana, Dominican Republic, Panama and Seychelles) have reported that 6 agreements are in progress. The case of India is special because it has granted more than 200 commercial permits during the year. Although there has been an important improvement in the number of commercial agreements, only 50% of the participating countries have reached their targets, which shows that few countries have in place ABS legal frameworks, a normal pre-requisite to negotiate any commercial agreement. The project continues its efforts to approve ABS national legal frameworks and it is also promoting regional and national trainings on negotiation of ABS contracts in partnership with the Union for Ethical Biotrade (UEBT).

1. 22
2. Albania: 52.42%; Belarus: 50.30%; Egypt: 36.67 %; India: 58.05 %; Jordan: 42.73%; Sudan: 44.24%; Colombia: 94.24%; Dominican Republic: 58.79%; Ecuador: 65.45%; Honduras: 58.79%; Panama: 70.91%; Uruguay: 12.12%; Botswana: 50%; Comoros: 50%; Ethiopia: 90%; Kenya: 70%; Rwanda: 50%; Seychelles: 80%; South Africa: 85%; Kazakhstan: 50 to 75%; Mongolia: 45 to 65%; Myanmar: 35 to 55%; Samoa: 50 to 75%; Tajikistan: 30 to 50%
3. 1 (per country in 21 countries) 2 in Mongolia and Uruguay (none in Ecuador)

FINAL RESULTS
1. All the countries have developed their draft ABS legal frameworks and, therefore, they have achieved their target. 2 countries have approved during this year different ABS legal instruments. Honduras adopted its ABS Regulation in May 2021 and Jordan approved in April 2021 its ABS Bylaw (previously had amended its Biodiversity Law to incorporate the necessary ABS principles). In total 8 countries have adopted ABS policies, laws and/or regulations (Albania, Comoros, Dominican Republic, Honduras, Jordan, Panama, Seychelles and Uruguay). Although the target had been achieved, the project continued pushing for the approval of the ABS laws and regulations in all the countries. Colombia and Rwanda, originally without a concrete target on this output, have also conducted different activities to support the improvement of their ABS legal systems.
2. The target has been achieved in 17 countries. Most of the countries have clearly exceeded their original percentage of increase, in some cases they have doubled them (Albania, Belarus, Dominican Republic, Jordan, Sudan). Only 6 countries have not reached their initial target of increase institutional capacity, 4 of them with a very small difference, inferior to 5% (Colombia, Ethiopia, Kazakhstan and Mongolia), and 2 countries with bigger gap to their targets (Panama, 11.5%; and Seychelles, 18%). Albania: 82.6%; Belarus: 76.81%; India: 81%; Jordan: 60.86%; Sudan: 65.22%; Colombia: 88.40%; Dominican Republic: 81,15%; Ecuador: 78%; Honduras: 66.66%; Panama: 59.42%; Uruguay: 52.17%; Botswana: 58%; Comoros: 78%; Ethiopia: 86%; Kenya: 69%; Rwanda: 89.9%; Seychelles: 62%; South Africa: 91%; Kazakhstan: 60.86%; Mongolia: 52.17%; Myanmar: 59.42%; Samoa: 79.71%; Tajikistan: 78.81%.
3. All the countries (22) have supported different biodiscovery projects (33 ouf of 24 initially expected) but also have developed strategies to promote bioprospecting activities in their countries for the active valorization of their genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge. In some cases, they have even developed a coordinating network which blends partnerships to optimize development and enhance growth, such as in the South African biotrade and bioprospecting sector (BioProducts Advancement Network South Africa, BioPANZA). Ecuador, initially not included in this specific output, has supported a biodiscovery partnership that includes not only a research institution from the USA, but a collaboration agreement with the indigenous community of San Jose de Payamino as key partners. Some of these collaborations have ended in the request of ABS commercial permits that shows the very concrete commercial potential of some of these biodiscovery projects. 10 out 22 countries have signed 38 ABS commercial agreements (Colombia, 18; Dominican Republic, 3; Ethiopia, 6; Kenya, 5; Myanmar, 1; Panama, 1; Seychelles, 1; South Africa, 2; Sudan, 1). The case of India is special because it has granted more than 200 commercial permits during the project. Although there has been an important improvement in the number of commercial agreements, only a limited number of the participating countries have reached their targets, which shows that few countries have in place ABS legal frameworks, a normal pre-requisite to negotiate any commercial agreement. The project has been until the end of the project supporting countries to approve ABS national legal frameworks and it has also been promoting regional and national trainings on negotiation of ABS contracts in partnership with other organizations, such as the Union for Ethical Biotrade (UEBT). The support of the project to different biodiscovery projects at the national level through national research institutions has mobilized researchers and put them at the heart of the ABS system at the national level, converting them into the key transformational agents of change in the country: putting into value the genetic resources of the country, channeling most of the benefit-sharing back to the country through innovation and biotech development, while promoting social justice and conserving biodiversity. ABS has brought a different approach and relationship between researchers and indigenous peoples and local communities, in most cases as necessary partners for research and development, based on respect and mutual trust.

1. 22
2. Albania: 52.42%; Belarus: 50.30%; Egypt: 36.67 %; India: 58.05 %; Jordan: 42.73%; Sudan: 44.24%; Colombia: 94.24%; Dominican Republic: 58.79%; Ecuador: 65.45%; Honduras: 58.79%; Panama: 70.91%; Uruguay: 12.12%; Botswana: 50%; Comoros: 50%; Ethiopia: 90%; Kenya: 70%; Rwanda: 50%; Seychelles: 80%; South Africa: 85%; Kazakhstan: 50 to 75%; Mongolia: 45 to 65%; Myanmar: 35 to 55%; Samoa: 50 to 75%; Tajikistan: 30 to 50%
3. 1 (per country in 21 countries) 2 in Mongolia and Uruguay (none in Ecuador)

Results until July 2019
1. 18 out of the 21 national ABS legal frameworks have been developed and submitted, including TK measures, and are at different levels of discussion for approval at the national level and the ones pending (Botswana, Kenya and Myanmar) are expected to be submitted in the coming months. A new ABS Regulation has been adopted in Panama (Executive Decree 19, 26 March 2019) and the ABS provisional measure adopted in Uruguay in November 2017 has been provided of the necessary legal basis with the approval of the amendment of article 22 of the Environment Act (the ABS Regulation is currently under discussion for its adoption). These legal bases have been crucial for the approval of the first ABS commercial agreement in Panama (June 2019) and the first 2 ABS non-commercial permits in Uruguay (March and June 2019). These legal developments join the complete ABS legal framework of Dominican Republic previously adopted in 2018 and the preexisting ABS legal frameworks in another 7 countries of the project (Belarus, Colombia, Ecuador, Ethiopia, India, Kenya and South Africa). The project is fully aware of the relevance of adopting the legal basis and ABS procedures at the national level as a precondition to put in value the genetic resources of the countries and it is working hard with national teams to identify and support key activities for their approval before the end of the project.
2. 13 countries out of 23 have already achieved their targets (57%). The target is on track in 10 countries and it is still trying to gather relevant data in some of the countries. - Albania: 50% Training session on mutually supportive implementation of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture and the Nagoya Protocol on Access and Benefit-sharing -ABS (17-18 December 2018); Belarus: 50%; Jordan: 40%; Sudan: 59%; Comoros: 38%; Ethiopia: 71%; Kenya: 62%; Rwanda: 62%; Seychelles: 59%; Colombia: 89%; Dominican Republic: 65%; Ecuador: 71%; Honduras: 60%; Panama: 73%; Uruguay: 25%; Botswana: 48% (165 stakeholders trained -74F/91M); South Africa: 77%; Kazakhstan: 75% (316 people trained - 163 M/153 F); Tajikistan: 40% (126 stakeholders trained); India: 59%; Mongolia: 47%; Myanmar: No data; Samoa: 55%
3. 8 commercial agreements have been signed since the beginning of the project (Colombia, Dominican Republic, India, Panama and South Africa) (33%), which shows that few countries have in place ABS legal frameworks, a normal pre-requisite to negotiate any commercial agreement. Regional and national trainings on negotiation of ABS contracts have been conducted in Latin America with the participation of 9 countries in partnership with the Union for Ethical Biotrade (UEBT) and at the national level in several countries (Comoros, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Sudan). Other regional trainings on ABS contracts are planned for the 2nd half of 2019. Negotiations will be promoted as soon as national ABS legal frameworks are in place. Another 8 commercial agreements are under negotiation. The target is on track.
